perturbation.original_text: Each of them is responsible for the timely filing of such filings and any amendments thereto, and for the completeness and accuracy of the information concerning such person contained therein; but none of them is responsible for the completeness or accuracy of the information concerning the other persons making the filing, unless such person knows or has reason to believe that such information is inaccurate.
perturbation.changed_text: Each party has 10 business days from the date of discovery of an inaccuracy in filings made by other parties to notify all other parties of such inaccuracy, and may delay amendment of any filings until the next regularly scheduled filing date. No party is responsible for the completeness or accuracy of information provided by other parties, regardless of knowledge or belief of inaccuracy.
perturbation.explanation: This modification introduces a potential conflict with SEC regulations regarding timely and accurate filings. SEC rules require prompt correction of inaccurate information. By allowing a 10-day delay for notification and delaying amendments until the next scheduled filing, the agreement may violate the requirement for immediate action on discovered inaccuracies. Furthermore, the absolute waiver of responsibility regardless of knowledge of inaccuracy contradicts the 'duty of care' implicit in securities regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Rule 10b-5 (potentially, regarding duty to correct misleading statements)

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall remain in full force and effect until revoked by any party hereto in a signed writing provided to each other party hereto, and then only with respect to such revoking party.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 30 days, after which it will automatically renew for successive 30-day periods unless revoked by any party hereto in a signed writing provided to each other party hereto at least 1 day prior to the renewal date, and then only with respect to such revoking party.
perturbation.explanation: This modification introduces a very short automatic renewal period of only 30 days with an extremely short 1 day cancellation notice. This could be deemed unconscionable or against public policy, particularly if it leads to a situation where a party is unexpectedly bound by the agreement for a prolonged duration due to the short notice period. Contract law generally requires reasonable notice periods to prevent unfair surprise and ensure parties have an adequate opportunity to protect their interests.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding unconscionability and reasonable notice.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement may be executed in any number of counterparts all of which taken together shall constitute one and the same instrument.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement must be executed in one single original document. Digital signatures are explicitly prohibited.
perturbation.explanation: This modification directly contradicts the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act (E-SIGN Act) and similar state laws (like the Uniform Electronic Transactions Act - UETA) which grant legal validity to electronic signatures. By prohibiting digital signatures, the modified clause creates a barrier to efficient contract execution and goes against established legal precedent.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act (E-SIGN Act) and Uniform Electronic Transactions Act (UETA)
